title: An argument with a false conclusion can be valid. true or false? - Quora

response.answer_text: An argument is said to be logically valid when it reaches a conclusion from its premises in accordance with the rules of logic. That does not mean the conclusion, or the premises, are true. For example: All people who take an immortality pill are immortal. Socrates took an immortality pill. Ergo, Socrates is immortal. That is a valid argument. It is not, however, true.
